content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Great to see the game on Steam!I am a long term player, so thought I would write up a review to include some of the things a new player will not notice instantly.So the basics:You will start off like most games, learning a few basic attacks and talents. Completing quests and killing creeps to level up your character. When you level up you will receive level up points (to place in melee, range stat etc) and I think after level 4 you will start to receive Talent points. This is when you can browse the talent trees and start to plan a path for your character.You are not limited to any of the class talent trees, which is something I really love. Theory crafting your builds and trying new things that no on else has thought of before can be very rewarding and fun, even when you get it completely wrong! For new players, you are granted a free full respec, so do not worry if you go wrong on your first attempt.I am currently messing around with builds to try in the pvp battlegrounds, and have made a tanky ranger which I am having lots of fun playing at the moment... pewpew! :POnce you level up and make a few friends you can start to tackle group dungeons, these dungeons reward relics which will allow you to buy the best armour sets available (at the dungeon level). If you prefer solo play, they have been adding "Story Mode" dungeons too. Here you can gain relics for those same armour sets, but story mode has slightly less loot than group dungeon(weapons etc).When you hit end game, you can group up and tackle the "Ascended" dungeons. These are buffed versions of the regular dungeons, much more difficult but much more rewarding! dropping better loot, and relics for the "Fabled Sets". When you are happy with your character and gear you can then start checking out pvp battlegrounds, world bosses, trolls that spawn randomly across the world.I do not really care for vanity, pets, mounts etc. but if you are a player who enjoys those things there are loads to collect! some are also only available when completing certain achievements. There are also tons of achievements too, if you enjoy those.If you want to grind Gold, you can do that. If you want to hardcore level up you can do that too. If you want to bum around and chat with your friends you can do that. I have had loads of fun grouping up with people I met in the game, to run dungeons, pvp or just mess around, but I am at heart a player who prefers solo play... and I have enjoyed going off on my own adventures too.I think there are currently 16 professions you can work on, example: Prospecting, Farming, Cooking, Alchemy etc. My advice for these... is stay away from Fishing! damn that is boring, unless you like fishing (of course).There are loads of quest to complete, and many players will find this the easiest way to level up early on. Once you get a grasp of the game, you can then decide what path is most fun for you. Hope this was useful! Enjoy the game :)

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Alright, so after 14 hours of very enjoyable play, I've decided it's time to write a review.This is going to be a fairly lengthy, very technical and detailed look at the game, from the perspective of an ex-Runescape player. If you played Runescape in the past, and are interested in nitty gritty mechanical details, then this review will be for you. I'm going to be comparing pretty much everything to how Runescape did things.TL;DR: Hands down recommended 100% to any ex-Runescape members. This game is overall absolutely fantastic, and I've just been filled with so much excitement and joy and nostalgia, on top of the fact that this game is better than Runescape in a lot of ways.Rather than Runescape where you have all of your skills mixed up on one tab, here your skills are sorted between two tabs: Gathering and Crafting.For Gathering, you have: Fishing, Skinning, Farming, Foraging, Forestry, Prospecting, and Crystal Cutting.For Crafting, you have: Cooking, Leatherworking, Tailoring, Alchemy, Weaponsmithing, Armorsmithing, and Jewelry.There is indeed a Skinning skill. Rather than RS where you kill a cow and it drops hide and a perfect little red and white steak, now you actually need a knife and can skin your animals, which will give you those, and skin as well. Very enjoyable difference.Smithing has been split up into Armorsmithing and Weaponsmithing. This makes sense and from a gameplay/economy perspective, promotes people to specialize in one or the other. I enjoy the change.Forestry is Woodcutting. Prospecting is Mining which includes smelting, rather than RS where smelting was considered part of Smithing. Foraging is what it sounds like, all different kinds of gathering, from apples to various plants which are used in alchemy. In RS, Herbalism was a combination of gathering herbs and alchemy.There is no general "Crafting" skill. It's all been split apart into different things, like Leatherworking and Tailoring and Jewelry and Crystal Cutting. It should be mentioned that getting crystals, or gems, is part of Prospecting.There's quite a few skills missing, although missing isn't really an accurate word. Construction and player housing is really the only skill missed. Strength, Attack, Defense, Ranged, and Magic aren't part of the skills set. You can make fires, though I'm not sure which skill it's a part of, or if it's just a thing on its own. Fires can be used to cook and provide a small "rested xp" area like a tavern.Prayer, Constitution, Dungeoneering, and obviously Runecrafting are also not included.Alright, so now I'm going to focus on mining a little.First of all, the animation is different and how you get ore is different. In RS, when you mine a node, you play through a lengthy animation, and at any time during this animation you can get a piece of ore. If you get ore, the animation is interrupted. If you don't, it just loops again. The animation was that you'd first take 3 little picks at the rock with the point of your axe, then take a couple short swings, then a really long hefty swing.With this game, you always take two short swings, and you always get ore after the two swings. Sometimes it's 1, in my experience it's almost always 2, sometimes you get 3, rarely you get 4. I'm not sure if this is influenced by level, it doesn't seem like it. I don't know if you can get more than 4.This is an extremely enjoyable difference. It's more realistic, a LOT faster, and from an animation standpoint is just purely better.On to crafting. Crafting overall, I really prefer how RS did it. RS was simpler. There are so many arbitrary ingredients thrown in to recipes, it's really annoying. For example, cooking. In order to make cooked meat, you have to have salt (which is bought) and basil (which is farmed). Why do I absolutely need these things in order to roast a slab of meat? Why can't I just make some unsalted, unseasoned meat? This is super frustrating coming from RS where you just toss the meat on a fire and call it good. In my opinion, you should have the option of adding salt. If you don't use salt, it should make regular "cooked meat". If you add salt, it should make "salted cooked meat" which would have better effects.Anyway, moving on to smelting. This is annoying too. In order to smelt copper ore, you need flux, and you need coal. Again, this is extremely annoying where in RS you just tossed the copper in. It makes sense to need flux, and it arguably makes sense to need coal to keep the furnace going, but needing a hunk of coal for every copper bar is just... frustrating.Random note, while it's nice that ore and different things STACK in general, it is annoying that they stack to different amounts. Copper bars stack to 5, copper ore stacks to 10, coal stacks to 25, flux stacks to 50... etc. So when mining you need to figure things out like you need 5 stacks of copper ore for every stack of coal. (because the recipe for smelting copper ore needs 1 coal, 2 copper ore, 1 flux.)Also, when mining you have a rare chance to get "pure copper ore". This is all well and good, but how this ore is used is a bit strange. The purpose of smelting regular copper is to get rid of impurities, and make it just copper, i.e. pure. So it makes no sense whatsoever for this "pure copper ore" to be used directly in crafting a superior piece of armor. The only difference between pure copper ore and a copper bar is that one is in the shape of a bar. They both get melted down and reshaped into the item anyway.From a gameplay perspective I get it, you have a rare chance to get something that'll allow you to make something better. That's fine. But from a realism standpoint, it makes no sense. I think that instead you should have a chance to make a "pure copper bar", which you managed to get more pure than normal.A quick note about farming. It's pretty fun. I haven't done much of it, and I never really did it in Runescape, but I can tell you it's a lot faster and a lot more engaging. Rake the plot, plant the seeds, add water, and it starts growing. Growing takes about 30 seconds. While growing it can start to develop some kind of disease so you need to prune to stop the spread. The more disease, the less yield you'll get from harvest. I like this system a lot.I'm just going to start bullet pointing things because I'm running out of space.The game isn't tile-based, you move exactly where you click, and can move using WASD and control the camera with RMB. It's pretty nice. You can also move by clicking on the minimap.The pathing distance is extremely small. So you can't path around buildings or fences, it's really annoying. If you click on the ground off in the distance, it only registers out a very small way. The same applies to actions. If you right click to open a door or attack an enemy, your guy will run up to that distance, then stop and say he's out of range.You can't set waypoints.It has WoW's hippogryph-style travel system, except with dragons.There are mounts.You have a homestone, again like WoW's hearthstone.You can't fly (mounts) or jump.---Overall, it does have its problems, but it just feels like a better, more modern Runescape.Give it a shot! You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												This is a indie MMORPG that has been around 8 years in the making. It has launched in November 2013. For a small team of artists, programmers and developers, they have done an amazing job with the game.What I like about Eldevin:You start off as your character - and Eldevin has a classless system, so you can choose/switch what class you'd like to be - from Warrior, Templar, Assassian, Ranger, Mage, Prophet or even a mixture. You gain talent points every time you level, and you can use those talent points in the tree of the class you wish to use. You also obtain points to increase your health, melee, mage, range etc.The storyline is interesting, and some quests allow you to interact and some allow you to choose the outcome. There are also a few puzzles which is another bonus for me.As long as you don't mind the graphics which kind of has a charming feel to the game itself.  There is alot of content to do, from training skills, to questing, to doing dungs with a team or by yourself (story mode). You can also explore the world of Eldevin, complete achievements, and obtain pets/mounts/vanity.While exploring Eldevin, you can also use forms of "fast travel" from using a dragon handler to travel to a place but requires money, to using a homestone which allows you to teleport to the one city that it's attuned to - with a few hours limit - and to buy portals to summon a friend to where you are - to instant dragon which immediatly teleports you to a place of your choice (but requires eldevin points). And yes, Eldevin is that BIG.This game is completley F2P. There are suscriptions available if you wish to recieve bonuses like earning more money/exp from quests/monsters that you kill.Eldevin also has a shop where you can purchase things with Eldevin Points - purchased with real life money or even in-game if you swap gold for EP with other players.You can buy mostly vanity/pets or you can also buy storage like sacks which helps carry your gathered/crafted resources. Fear not, if you can't buy sacks, there is a baby version known as baskets - which you can buy with in-game money - the only difference that it'll hold less. Same goes with backpacks (which gives you more inventory space).There are other things you can buy like skill boosters (gives more exp in gathering/crafting skills).Combat:You can use auto-attack feature to attack NPC's quickly, with the two basic abilities - melee and range.There is also abilities that you can use, either purchased from a NPC shop for in-game money, or unlocked from the Talent Tree.Since it's classless, you are not restricted to one class, and can use abilities from other classes - like healing yourself.Using abilities however uses MANA, so fortunatley there are ways to restore mana through potions/food or letting it restore itself.PVM:PVM can be found in dungs, ascended dungs (hardmode version) and world bosses as well as quest bosses. PVP:There is an area where you can fight other players, gather useful loot, and even fight a world boss when it spawns. So be sure to look out for Trapper's Atoll aka the Wilderness. :)There are also PVP modes you can do as well.Other Modes:There are other modes then just dungs.You can fight in the Eldevin Arena - facing against monsters in a team (not sure if its also solo), and fight in the Trail of Champions. Skills:There are 14 skills in total, which 7 is gathering, and the rest is crafting.Gathering:You can gather items in many places/areas in Eldevin. Different resources spawn in different areas. Crafting:The crafting system is a bit more in-depth, where you don't just need raw resources to make... mage gear as an example. You convert the raw resource and wool into cloth, then you use cloth/thread to make that gear.However, some gears are basic. There are gears which require more resources in order to make it. You can either buy those resources, or obtain them yourselves from doing Dailys and dungs.Another example would be cooking. You don't just need fish, but also items gained from Farming/Foraging. Each type of food has a benefit for a certain class. It can also heal you/restore Mana - but can't use during combat. That's for potions made from the skill Alchemy.What I don't like:Typically you can level up by doing quests, but you can also grind on mobs to gain experience to level up - and sometimes that is only way you can level up and continue doing quests which requires certain levels to complete.Some quests can be boring, like kill that/obtain this for me, and bring it back. Those are usually side quests though.There is no Guilds or Auction Houses yet but it's in the plans of the Hunted Cow Studio team, and thus the wait still continues :). However the postives outwiegh the negatives for me, because the team is willing to listen to feedback - and theres alot of content to enjoy in the game.>I would totally recommend this game to you, if you're looking for a new MMORPG to play.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												TLDR;  Indie mmo game with good mechanics of gameplay, just try it yourself - it is around 70mb client Imagine the crafting and gathering system from the old classic Runescape, mixed with the World of Warcraft gameplay.We've got balanced formula of crafting activities and progressing the main storyline, which isn't that obvious. Game isn't making me more tired after few hours of play.While playing we aren't bound to any typical mmorpg class scheme. We've got 6 different talent class tables - we can spend the talent points ( earned upon lvling) any way we want to. Worth noting is that we can't make superhero skilled in every possible way either. We got to decide wether we want to deal with magics/meele/ranged and use them as our main force.Now onto the community, currently we're all waiting for the update adding guilds feature - but people start making small communities anyway. Character creater once is accessible on every currently online server (we've got separate ones for US, EU, Asia.. ). Everyone is friendly and helpful, game developers are very often updating the game in the evening (eu time) and playing the game itself also. As a quality of the game I will add little story, that happened to me :"Some ranger was selling pretty nice 19lvl rare drop 2handed sword in world chat. The sword's value was 10gold coins - that's pretty much for a early players like me.Seller understood I can not afford the sword yet and offered me this sword for a skinning activity - which took me about 10minutes to gather desired skins."Forgot to mention - the game is developed by indie studio, they're doing great work there. I can recommend it not only for anyone who misses the old runescape times but anyone else interested in playing a well developed game.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Lovely RPG MMO, you've got 14 skills to train (divided to gathering and crafting, 7 skills for both), up to lvl 47 each(at this moment).Training a skill, such as Leatherworking, requires you to get animal hides and skins, then make leather. With leather, you can make Medium Armors.Plenty of dungeons to do, skills to train, money to farm, item sets to collect etc.Liked/always wanted to try out Runescape? Then this game is totally worth of trying out!Really enjoyable with a group of friends, especially if you have Melee/Tank, Ranged/DPS and Healer teammates for Dungeon runs. Or PvP (CTF or TDM)Definitely "Thumbs Up" from me, even though there's Pay to Win elements.Pros Events! Party hats! HATS! You wont run out of things to do too quickly Multiple "currencies", smilar to Guild Wars 2 14 Skills to train World feels really big. There's 5 "areas", if I remember right You can pick up manure (its true) Mounts and fast travelling (riding dragons, whoo!), so you dont have to go everywhere by foot! You can get XP for your "overall" level without actually fighting. Just train skills, you'll get some extra XP (you wont get much, but hey, better than nothing) Wont take much space on your hard drive. Barely anything, to be honest Doesnt need good PC to run - Has some FPS issues though. See below  I almost got killed by small beetle, that was "only" 4 levels higher than me (is this good or bad thing? Bosses are actually hard to solo (I am looking at you, Guild Wars 2) - assuming that you are equal/lower lvl than they areNeutral Its Runescape-like "Pay to win" ? I am not totally sure about this, but yep, you can buy many useful thing from the store with real money, such as (massive) extra inventory bags, various boost potions, etc. Spend few bucks, and you dont have to farm for money that much. I guess this is the price of the Free to Play game. They must get that money from somewhere, right? However everything (expect "Premium") can be obtained, as long as you have enough of Gold to trade for Eldevin Points (Premium currency) Daily quests - Both really nice and bad idea. You get Artisan Points (these are used to buy all kind of useful things) plus little cash and XP, when you complete those. The only problem is, that they're really boring and lame. Make/Get X amount of Y things. You can just run around the city, claiming your rewards from all daily tasks(once in a day, of course), if you've got those resources in your inventory No Auction House - you must sell everything to stores or trade with players. However, they'll add this later though! No Guilds - You'll have a hard time organizing huge player groups, since there's a player limit in Groups. However, like Auction House, they'll add this later as well I found 'tutorials' a little bit weird (skilling) Music - I love it, but it gets repetive, since there's not that many different tracksCons Bots? I'd say that there's plenty of Bots in the starting place's Mine. That place is always crowded, no matter what time it is. Or prehaps everyone are just so excited about Armor/Weaponsmithing? Training enough of both (lets say, lvl 11 both of them?) takes a while, though Sometimes you have to wait pretty long to do Dungeon runs. Waiting over 1h isnt fun. I cant say if this is problem only on EU server, or on other servers as well? You do NOT want to do one quest at the time. Running back and forth - you'll just spend most of your time going from place A to B then. Try to do all quest in that area at once You can buy in-game money(note; only the "main currency"), with real world money! - This is really stupid in my opinion, kids with their parent's credit cards/ people with extra dosh can get ridiculous amounts of in-game money, without actually doing anything. Expect "wasting" their money Uh, graphics...? I am fine with them, but the character models, for example, looks pretty edgy-ish Barely any graphical settings. Only Resolution, Fullscreen on/off, capped FPS on/off, View Distance, Texture Filter, Anisotropy and Rendering, and "Enable Low Texture Resolution" thingy World is pretty empty. Too much emptiness, without real purpose Random FPS drops - In City, you'll encounter FPS spikes. Mine swings between 4 and 50 FPS, which is really weird, since I can run at least Skyrim with maxed settings (and some graphics mods). This cant be so heavy game.... How to see FPS(without using any third party programs)? Just type /fps in chat  Clunky camera (controls) - Do NOT use WASD(movement keys) AND turn the camera at the same time. Camera randomly resets, ending you to suddenly change your direction. Hopefully they will fix this soon Most of the items (equipment) that you can buy from NPCs, are really expensive. I see no reason buying any weapons/armors from NPCs. Just make your own, do some Dungeon runs or trade with players During character creation, you have only few things you can change, such as face or body colour. Also, the characters are pretty ugly. But remember, this is only my opinion!I'll give it 4,20 Smuggled Strawberries out of 5.Extra; There was a nude gathering in the city. It was weird. They invited me in. Now I have weird friends.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												Games pretty silly in the end, only way to actually level crafting (without spending 500hrs per gather and 2000hrs per craft) is in the pvp zone, where you will just get bombarded all day with server jumpers from the US server no matter what server you play on. I actually subscribed for 1 month and also bought the cheap package on steam. Still never had enough space in bags after spending over 2500gold (gold limit is 1100gold if you dont pay monthly) on bag upgrades and 2000 eldevin points on sacks and bag upgrades as well as the steam backpack from paid package. Dont even think about playing warrior class if you want to do any pvp or even gather resources as said before the areas are constantly bombarded by server jumpers who have played for a year with max gear and only come on to kill lower level players.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This game is good, but by no means excellent.I've been playing since release and was a beta tester for a little bit (but some have been testing a lot longer than i).What this game really is a disguised pay to play game.If you look at the subscription you'll understand why.You have to unlock certain components for a character, and if you do not want to have all of those things right away, it will take some time to be able to access (if you're slowly gathering ep [in game currency bought with cash]) or being a hardcore trader able to make the sales.the limitation for a f2p player is a bit harsh, but if you can find a way to unlock the the character limitations then it's no problem. It's how you will do it will be either a pain or not.The leveling can get a bit slow at times, especially when you run out of quests (which you will at some points) and have to grind mobs or run dungeons according to your level.non combat skills are great. the game dialogue and story are very, well written.Certain aspects about combat need to be addressed, but it's ultimately how smart you are with every thing that dictates how well you do in a team fight (but 1v1 some classes will just eat you if you're not with out help)The lack of environment expansion (in regards to size and the camera angle) make the maps a little squishes and the mob spawn rate can seem a bit over whelming at times, but it's nothing you can handle.The big thing i like about eldevin is that it adds a bit of suspense when leveling solo. You almost always need to be on your toes (at least for less armored people) and have pots available, or a side kick.This game is very deserving of the 2013 best f2p mmo awar that it was given.If you play this game hardcore, you will get bored and frustrated.This is not world of warcraft, and is even less of a design clone from it too.But, it's fun.8.5/10Big ups and good luck.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Here is my Eldevin Review.I can not recommend this game to anyone.It is not even close to being finished, a lot of content that makes a mmo is not present.The player base is extremely low, and mostly kids / students.  I mean players who are either still in grade school, high school or a few in college playing the game and doing homework at the same time. I tell this so that you know how the community is for the game.  In all the time I have been here and played on all 3 servers I only talked with one other player who is my age, over 30. Even if the game were populated by people my own age entirely I could in all fairness not recommend it. The current player base is toxic and because of the lack of content at max level / end game it appears that only bullies and thugs stay at max level 45 which I will cover in detail later on.  At best it is mmo lite, if you have never played a mmo in your life you might start here and learn the ropes.PVP – Most new players coming here ask about PVP.  PVP is dead, it is broken and virtually non existent in this game.  There is one small open PVP map in the game called Trappers Atoll, TA.  Here players can enter starting at level 15.  They have not tiered the map at all.  Max level 45 players freely roam this tiny map freely killing players who are 30 levels lower then they are.  It is pretty much the only thing a level 45 can do besides run the final dungeon again for fun at end game.  There are standard 4 on 4 PVP matches that last 10 minutes assuming you can find 8 people to join.  Again the matches are not tiered and you have a 15 and a 45 level in the same match.  Nothing about it I would call PVP.  Again, this is both true in the PVP map and the PVP matches.  Both of them are not tiered.  It is not just the bullying but having someone who played the game over a year with the best gear and best weapons and best gems in the same area as someone who played the game for 4 hours, come on really????????Graphics – The game is a browser game.  It is closest to Runescape with a tad better graphics. If you want eye candy for your new super charged machine look elsewhere.  I personally do not care about graphics, my first PC game was civ 1 by Sid Meirs in grade school to give you an example here.  I know that other people now a days do care.Sound – Again same as graphics.  Characters – The game states to be classless.  I have found that it is really worse then having a fixed class.  All of your talents and spells and stats are based off of the primary weapon you will use throughout the game.  If you pick up a bow and start to use a bow you will only pick talents and spells that uses a bow.  If you want to say play a ranger and use bows and swords you will be out of luck. Then there is the 2-hand weapon guy, the 2 1-hand weapon guy, the 1-hand sword and shield guy and finally your mage.There is not really much variety here, level 45 player builds all look the same with no variety.Crafting / Professions there are 14 and you can learn any of them and max them out at level 45.Please note that currently there is no mailbox or auction house and the populaton on servers drops down to as low as 30 during slow periods of the night.  So if you are thinking of crafting or gathering to raise gold it it pretty much pointless at this time.Quests – The standard go fetch x items, go talk to this npc here, run around the map back and forth.  Again nothing new here.  I got really tired of the run from this city to the other city, talk to a NPC then run back.  Only to find that as soon as you complete that quest the same NPC has you run to the same city you just came from to talk to another NPC 2 feet away.Pay to Win – Not really.  The only bad downside is the fact that there are things here to buy with real cash that are not available for a free to play player.  The worse example is the backpack.  A free to play player can buy and upgrade bags costing thousands of gold pieces for a normal bag each.  A backpack, which holds about twice or three times the best bag a free to play player still costs over $15 in real money to buy.  Also note that you can have multiple bags in both your inventory and in the bank.  There is also no way to extract / upgrade gems except for using real money.  So keep in mind if you put a gem in a slot it will cost real money if you want to use it later on or upgrade it to the next level. There is a cap on gold for free to play players and with a subscription it is removed.  Also a subscriber earns 2x as many relics when running a dungeon so they get the best gear twice as fast.Finally a subscriber will earn an extra 25% more gold from loot drops and when they sell items to a vendor.Loyalty program – What a joke.  You earn 5 tokens a day when you log in.  Then you can turn these points in for free stuff.  Let me give you an example of what they want to reward you with.  For 10 loyalty tokens you can buy a little bit of copper.  Copper is the first metal you can mine in the game, it is found all over the entire map and the amount you get for free you can mine in less then 1 minute on the map.  If the intention is to keep players coming back to play they failed miserably here. Dungeons – You get a new dungeon every 5 levels except for level 30.  The best gear and loot drops from them.  They have opened a can of worms here as well.  There are 2 ways to run a dungeon.  If you have a full party of 5 you can run the dungeon in dungeon mode like a standard mmo dungeon.  However, they also have a story mode where as little as 1 player can enter and do the same dungeon with the monsters being 1/5 health and fewer of them and the loot drop greatly reduced. So now it is almost impossible to get a full dungeon party together because at any time a single player can just run through the dungeon and not have to wait.  You also have a few problems with groups of 5 players speed running the dungeons in story mode to just farm the bosses for relics getting the best gear that way.  There is also a loot system where players can pass, greed or need items that drop.  This creates all sorts of head aches as some players will need on everything and have a better chance to win the loot rolls and they get kicked out quick.Another problem with story mode is players never learn how to play and run dungeons with other players.  At end game and the hardest dungeons, where team work is key to victory, these players have no clue how to work together.Mounts – Yes they have horses and other things to ride here.  As soon as you have 6 gold you can buy the first level ride skill for 5 gold and a flying disc for 1 gold.  There is no mail system or auction house in game.  It may or may not be coming sometime in the future.  This means the only way to trade items is to spam world chat and hope that the one player who may buy/sell you something is on at the same time you are.  It makes crafting and gathering to make gold rather pointless since chances are pretty good no one on will be buying that one thing.This is kind of hard to do when the player base drops to as low as 30 players actually online during the slow periods of the night. The highest I have seen on at one time during my time here is 800 on a weekend during the christmas break when all of the students were out of school.  I understand that the staff is tiny they have more games to support then developers currently.  It is easy to check how many players are on.  Just type /who in chat line and it gives you the number. I tired to cover everything you might want to learn about the game before playing it yourself.At this time of writing I put in just over 400 game hours, my character was max level, all of my quests were done and I have run all dungeons at least once.  Now I choose to leave instead of going to TA and killing brand new players so hopefully some of them will stay past level 15 and play the game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I do not recommend this game because it has deteriorated into vanity updates for money. Mainly with half baked releases of content, such as a barely there guild system. Their development cycle for any content is massive and hunted cow studios interaction with the community is very limited. A lot of the player base left for numerous reasons and when they first released on steam their population increased due to curious people. This did not last and they rapidly lost the new people who checked the game out.  Getting dungeons on the small player base is very hard.  On average you are talking 100 odd players over 3 servers and they are mainly the hardcore holdouts that are left hoping. They use a lot of asset reskins to put out vanity. This game if you were to play, get to know the small pop and hope to find someone willing to let you tag along on dungeons. They have also some solo dungeons, but mysteriously have stopped them after a certain point even though the population is not there.  For instance on other mmorpg games from what I have played, you have varied options to dungeon and find gear with smaller groups and decent gear. Here they limit your gem finding abilities and gear and almost make you feel ashamed you were forced to go solo. Then after a while you don't have the solo dungeon option as stated. Five man dungeons are the model really and at a certain point, you will need to try to get into them. The queue system is a no go, you can queue there for days, they will never fill. You need to find a group through people you know or chat hopefully.The game could do with more listening to the community and a big injection of development staff and more content options. If you look at the servers, us or eu, These are the ones to go too with a hand full usually online. The third server is empty virtually and just used for farming items.  Pvp island you can gather on. The pvp zone is pretty light on players, but will have a few who like to troll the gathers and kill them as they try to collect items here. I can only assume the island was so devoid of people the developers at one point decided to add nodes for crafters to come collect there to be targets to satisfy pvpers. You can gather outside of course in safe areas at a slower rate. But one can hazard a guess if so they wished why they want crafters on the pvp island. The questing is pretty much standard. Kill x amount of creatures, hand in quest, get xp or item. Can you give this item to someone for me, you run off hand in. Can you kill x amount of this creature until they drop x amount of items so I can have them, go gather then return for xp. Stuff like that. Unless you made friends be prepared for the roadblock at the end as you need dungeons for end gear or I guess buy the materials.  I think that covers most aspects of the game, I will briefly discuss the crafting, you basically gather or buy a rake of materials and take them to crafting stations plant character there and have them work away until the mats are gone. You either go gather more materials then or buy more.  Guilds are bare bones and pvp maps limited and very few playing. No auction house either and it is almost 2016, really mind blowing to even have to type that. There is a subscription payment option also if you want faster exp gain etc and some eldevin points monthly. Check the hcs store for pricing.On a finishing note if you do play. Gold will come easy later in game so do not panic. Eldevin is the currency you buy from other players or hunted cow studios and is far rarer. It is a paid for currency with very limited ways to get it, maybe at end game harvesting gems and selling them to other players for eldevin points. Dungeons give the most easy access to get gems. But you need those dungeon runs, some will get them, others not so muc. Overall, I will say this game should still be in beta and should never have been released for so long without basics in place. But it was released and I reviewed it as a finished product. They need to refocus as a dev team and get away from vanity releases and back to proper content. If you disagree with my review, feel free.  But it is my point of view and I ask you just respect that. It is my opinion. You can play or have played and feel differently.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												First off please ignore time played as I play this outside of steam.  The only reason I downloaded through steam was to be able to leave a review.This game is AMAZING!  It could easily be my #1 MMO but there are a couple of problems.  First and foremost the developers simply don't pay attention to feedback.  Now that's fine, everyone has opinions and I'll agree it's good to have a development team with a vision and who stick to their guns.  Problem is they're shooting themselves in the foot.  There's one MAJOR flaw with this game that has been brought up repeatedly and IMO is something that keeps it from achieving a much greater level of success.  That problem is - Arbitrary level restrictions.This game has all the hallmarks of a wonderfully open ended sandbox, crafting, and exploration MMO, but it's hog tied by a STUPID and POINTLESS level restriction system that prevents you from going anywhere or even taking a quest that's more than ONE LEVEL above your current level.  It's absolute insanity that they would ruin such potential with something so pointless.  I've played MMOs for well over a decade and I've never experienced something so ridiculous.A ONE level difference between friends, family members, or people you meet in the game, will make playing this game together a NIGHTMARE.  It needlessly burdons players who want to play together and playing with others is the very definition of MMO.PLEASE remove the level restrictions, or at least relax them.  More importantly, let people play the way they want.  If they want to explore higher level areas or take higher level quests and get in over their heads - let them.  That's part of the fun.  That's what makes MMO worlds exciting.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												You might have noticed that this review is long. Very long. Before you start reading the next one, I have a TL;DR and Pros and Cons for if you're too lazy to read the whole thing:TL;DR: I wouldn't rate this game very high. A 7/10 at most. Still, it's fun if the few cons don't bother you.Pro:- A very nice storyline. Maybe not very original, but definitely engaging.- Not a lot of paid content. Most content is accessible without having to pay real money.- Very large world.- A bunch of cool dungeons that you can beat solo as well as in a group.- A lot of the armour looks really cool and original.- The UI looks very good.Con:- A bit unoriginal as an MMO.- A lot of (mostly vanity) items are very, VERY expensive, either in real life or ingame currency.- Armour can not be worn as vanity. No matter how cool it looks, once its outdated you can't show it off anymore.- At least in my opinion, the look of the game is not very good. The graphics seem old and the aesthetics are nothing great either.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Eldevin. Your average MMO, to be honest. It doesn't really have a lot to separate it from the crowd; This being both a good and a bad thing.For example, if you're used to other MMOs, it's probably very easy to get in to. But on the other side, why would you, since it's not very different from said MMOs? Well, it of course has *some* elements that most others don't have. For one, the percentage of content you have to pay for to be able to use is very low. The little bit of paid content it does have is also mostly (if not all) vanity stuff, and no entire areas of the map that you have to pay $29,99 for to unlock. So, there's that for a difference with most other MMOs.The world is very large, but most of it isn't accessible until you're a higher level. Well, it is accessible of course, but not recommended. Most mobs are aggressive, so it's difficult to survive in higher leveled areas.The different skills, talents and classes allow for a bunch of different play styles, but quests and sometimes even the storyline will force you to use specific skills and thus upgrade them even if you wouldn't really need them except for those few quests.There's a bunch of 'group instances' throughout the game. They all have their own loot, which includes cool-looking armour sets, weapons, etc. They can be beat in Story Mode (single player, no loot gotten, mainly for quickly doing story quests) and Group Mode (multiplayer, loot divided between group members, all mobs get buffs to be challenging for 5-player groups).I've seen some complaints about the look of the game and yeah, I agree. The graphics look old to me. While without a doubt some like it, I think it makes the game look outdated. Nor the characters nor the terrain have much detail, and just look like something your average game in 2003 could best. The aesthetics aren't great either. The characters move a bit rigid (which is something we see a lot, though). Of course this is understandable because Eldevin isn't some big super blockbuster AAA 300 million dollar game but still. The UI looks good, though. With a lot of small games you see that the UI is just a bunch of grey, half-transparent squares with numbers or text in Times New Roman, but the UI in Eldevin looks very nice.There's maybe not very many different vanity items compared to other games that have just been out for much longer, but there's enough to make each player that has invested some time in the game look different from eachother. A lot of the vanity is (once again) very, very expensive. Either in the sense that it costs a lot of real life money (not very common in this game but it happens) or a lot of ingame money. For example the vanity bought with Prestige Points. Prestige Points are earned by doing some daily quests around the game. Players who have 'just' started playing will get 4 per day at most, more experienced players will get around 10 if they do their best. During Christmas you can get much more (>100 per day is possible, but you'll have to grind christmas mobs for hours). Even then, they're SO EXPENSIVE. One vanity set costs (I think) 50,000 prestige points. I might be horribly wrong, but at this scale, it doesn't matter much. That's why the costs of most vanity items are my main (but almost my only) complaint.I could name more examples and rant about it for hours but I'm already writing a bit too much. So yeah.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
 Amazing Experience! This game is great, and I've thoroughly enjoyed my experienc thusfar and will continue to play hopefully for a long while.First of all, this game hits that nostalgia factor, as at times it can feel somewhat like runescape. This is mostly due to the different skills and professions you can get yourself into, such as mining, making weapons, leatherwork, cooking, fishing, jewlery making, and much more. It feels nostalgic and rewarding to level up skills that tie in with your play style in order to provide for yourself and sell/supply to others. _________________________________--Overview--Pros: In-Depth storyline Many skills/professions to become skilled in Great community Enjoyable sidequests Diverse world Great for playing in a groupCons: Dwindling playerbase Outdated graphics (Not a con for me personally, as I find the grapics charming, though many people want better graphics._______________________________Premium CurrenciesA big point I like to make about this game is the fact that it does have a premium currency, though it is only for vanity items and special weapons. Throughout the game you will never have premium items shoved in your face unless you choose to visit the shop yourself to see what there is.Questing/ObjectivesQuesting can be fun and rewarding in this game as well. There is an in-depth main storyline which can lead to side-quests, but there are also tons of npc's around the world to get tasks from. In addition, there are quests to start you off in various skills, such as learning how to make weapons from ore, tailor clothes, farm a successful garden, or brew your own potions. The quests can lead you to new, interesting areas, and the big quests involve some depth and are not ridden with fetch objectives. All in all, I've enjoyed most of the quests, and the npc's who give them to you have character and are interesting to interact with.The WorldThe world itself isn't the largest, though it is diverse and it is more expansive than I originally thought when starting out at the beginning of the game. Some quests lead you to  new regions outside the map of the main city and wilderness, but you can find cool areas simply by exploring. Be weary, though, and possibly bring a friend, for you may run into particularly aggressive high-level creatures during your ventures. Throughout the world, characters have connections between areas, and the general feel of the game is prevelant with npc's of different regions.Group/Party PlayPlaying with a group is great. A couple of my friends and I decided to start this game together, and have chosen to focus on certain roles individually (I level up mining and weapon/armor crafting as well as being a melee warrior, one of us is an archer and levels in alchemy for potions, and another is our mage, leveling in magic with focus on healing and supplies us with food and charms). This system works great, as certain quests will lead you to group bosses, or raids, and it is a good idea to have backup on different roles. Also, you get an XP boost and can complete objectives simoultaneously to finish quests faster (defeating x/x enemies counts up together so you don't have to do it twice). CommunityThe community is great as far as I can tell. Starting out a random guy gave me a couple premium currency for free in a trade, which I was greatful of, and me and another similarly leveled player focused on different tasks (me mining, him farming) and exchanged goods to help each other out after randomly meeting. The only thing detrimental is the fact that the amount of players playing this game is dwidling. I hope people in the community can help to kindle a bigger playerbase, because with more players there will be more opportunity to trade and sell services to one another which would make the whole game experience even better.Final VerdictOverall this game is awesome. I've enjoyed grinding skills that I'm interested to supply my friends with better gear and sell to other players. The quests are enjoyable and the storyline has depth, so the whole experience can be quite immersive at times. There is opportunity to build your character whichever way you want, and group play adds to the experience. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes games like runescape as well as people who like fulfilling questlines or are just looking for a good f2p mmo.

												This game is great.  it captures what made runescape great, mixes it with familiar, traditional mmo mechanics, a friendly, if sometimes childish community and a generally uninvasive payment system that allows free players to experience ALL game content, with no ad interruptions or annoying "pay me" prompts outside of a "SHOP" button in the top right of the screen.  Currently, the game lets you level to 50, which is pretty difficult due to a long xp bar, but lot's of mmo's were like that while they found their "butter zone".Paying players do enjoy "benefits",  but if you invite your friends. you can get about 4-5 bucks worth of in-game cash once they hit level 20!   Each!All in all, i feel very happy with this game, and it's made my like-hate relationship with runescape alot easier to deal with.If you'd like to level with me, click this link, sign up, and then send "MarmaladeBath" a message!https://www.eldevin.com/invite/UUJADWGLNWESYOVDHave fun guys!

Short Review / Comparison about Eldevin>RuneScape?To make it short for people who played RuneScape.Eldevin is similar to runescape in some ways. I won't go into details, because even though it has similarity, its still diffrent.If you've played runescape and got bored by all the VIP only features, check Eldevin out.>Team PlayersEldevin doesn't have a massive player base. So I recommend to grab a few friends for the start.>Complaints about Inventory spaceI've seen many people complaining how Backpack space is way to expensive and you have not enough space for your items. Which is not really true. I did buy the DLC's shich contains bigger backpacks, but it's not necessary. If you clean up your inventory and save up some gold for Baskets there should be no problem.>Pay2Win?Not at all, you can simply buy cosmetics in the shop. And later on, getting Gold is so easy that you don't even have to buy cosmetics for actual money. The ingame currency is stable at Gold:EldevinPoints(EP) 3:1Important: If you decided to buy EldevinPoints, DO NOT buy gold from the Shop.>My overall playtimeCompared to other MMO RPG's my playtime is quite much. It's very fun to play with friends and Guild Members, specially if there's an event active.>Events / UpdatesThe game has for every international holiday an event ready. Sometimes they have bigger updates and fixes. Whenever an event goes online, there are quite a few bugs and glitches, where you can't finish your event quest. But thats no big deal since the devs fix it right away - 1 day.>I read your review, I still don't know if I should try itTry it. It's free. The only thing that could happen is, that you buy Eldevinpoints at the very beginning and realize that you don't like the game. But I don't think people are that stupid anyways. Have fun trying it out.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												As long as you do not require top-notch graphics to enjoy a game, this game will be enjoyable for you. It has all the elements you'd expect in an RPG, and it's built to run in a web browser too! A lot of reviews reference to Runescape, and yes I can see how you might compare the game to it, but being in a browser is probably the closest reason for that comparison. This game has plenty of unique features that will keep you busy.Lots of solo and co-op content, in fact the dungeons even come with a "story" mode, if you prefer to play alone. The monsters are easier, and you don't need a bunch of buddies to take the dungeon. However, if you want a challenge, run the dungeon normally and get the full experience.Lots of crafts to keep you busy, piles of quests and content, and a diverse user-built class system, which you can change with a free respec every 60 days if you decide to. Fun PVP zones, arena challenges, seasonal events, lots going on in the game to keep your interest.There is of course a pay for shop, but its not required to enjoy the game. The subscription benefits are nice, but only reduce the grind if you feel the need. The game progresses at a steady rate even without the buff. I've only been playing about a week now, but I see myself sticking to it for quite awhile. Will update my review as I go.What have you got to lose? Its free, give it a try! See you in game.

												I have put a few hours into this game and have come to really love it. I played World of Warcraft for years and Eldevin ranks right along with it. The one thing missing is a Auction House. The rest is there including Mailboxes!! The only downside to the mail system is that it requires Eldevin Points to send items. The Points can be purchased or IF you have an item that other players want you can trade them for the points. Most of the players are friendly and will help you out. (Total Strangers Helping you out really!!) The story lines are really easy to understand and you can do most everything by yourself IE: Dungs. These have an option that you can run the Dung on "Story Mode" and you can solo them but make and take lots of healing pots, mana pots etc..Storage is an issue and you will soon see the need for Bags. These you can either buy from other players or from the game store "They cant be made". You can however gather many items and make things yourself such as weapons, armor, potions, and even mounts. I do however recommend you stay out of the PvP areas until you are leveled and geared for it because most of the chars in this area are maxed in lvl and gear. I LOVE IT!!! Eat your heart out WoW!! You have been Replaced!!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												I am not an MMO player. I do not enjoy MMOs or their communities. Most of the time, if a game is listed as MMO I avoid it, and the MMOs I do try I get around 5-to-6 hours in before calling it quits... This game broke that. It's not what one would call "pretty", but its humor and storytelling more than make up for that. The mechanics are solid, with an incredibly immersive world that never seems to wind down. There's never a true calm period, as you always see people in a mad rush (at least, in the opening areas; I'll touch on that more when I get pass the Copper-age). The story and plot are cliched, but the way they are portrayed make such a huge difference, and the fact that some portions of the story can be different from anothers by simply choice add so much to replayability and roleplay, as well as gives everyone a potentially different story to swap and love. Overall, if you are looking for that one retro-feel game that can really cure that itch for an MMO, this is probably the one. Now, if you will excuse me, I think my 250 copper bars are done...

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
Product received for free
												After installing this game and playing it for a small period of time, I can safely say I'm hooked. I was cautious about the game at first, but after playing it, I think the game is worthwhile anyone's time who enjoys a classic MMORPG. I'll break down the pro's and the con's of the game, and explain why they are in their respective places.The Pro's:1.) There are no classes. You create your own class through the talent system and various abilities you learn as you level.2.) The game is very punishing in terms of not respecting mobs. Especially "elite", "champion", or "boss" mobs.3.) The game feels very interactive with you and your character, very rarely are you not doing something while in combat from my experience.4.) The game is complex, and not in a bad sense, but in terms of that the game doesn't hold your hand past the tutorial, and you have a lot of information to understand and process in order to play efficiently and effectively.5.) There is plenty to do, between quests, events, professions, dungeons, etc.6.) The game has a very small community. This can be a good or bad thing depending on preference, however, because of this, you make friendships with other players very easily, and for the most part, all of the players are very helpful, respectful, and welcoming of new players.7.) The game doesn't feel like a stereotypical MMORPG Grindfest. This may be more relating to the fact that the combat is very interactive in the game.8.) No pay to win garbage. Nearly everything from the cash shop can be purchased with in-game gold at some point or another. (Gold to Paid-Currency Ratio is about 1:3) All of the items from the cash shop are either purely cosmetic, or serve such a minimal purpose, it doesn't impact you.9.) The graphics. I know plenty of people will disagree with me here, but I do enjoy the simplicity of the game's art-style. It's very original and appealing to look at. It's not an overly-glamorous professional graphics design, with high resolution textures and models. Whilst, I do like very high-end graphics, and I give full respect for those who can do such, it's become the norm. Therefore, it's nothing special. These graphics, however, are, in my opinion.10.) The questing isn't linear. I can't go from level one to max level running in basically a straight line.The Con's:1.) (Intended or not) There [appears] to be an issue with auto-attacking where it must remain on your action bars, and you must use the action-slot that it's in, in order to auto-attack. This is not significant in any way, shape, or form, and is only a personal qualm of mine.2.) Not being able to track multiple quests at once can be a tad tedious at times, but it's nothing significant.3.) There appears to be quite a few issues with collision boxes on some in-world items. (I.E: Trees, boxes, etc.)4.) Updates are few and far in between, which, can be a good or bad thing, depending on the way you look at it. It's good if you are a casual player trying to progress to max level, it will give you quite a length of time to get there and not feel the rush or obligation to do so as soon as humanly possible. It's bad if you are already at the end-game, and are sitting on your hands with nothing to do, assuming you've accomplished every thing possible up to that point.Overall? I give this game a 10/10 in honesty. The cons are so insignificant it truly doesn't impact the gameplay enough for me to want to dilute my rating of the game.TL;DR - If you get past the graphics, if you are a graphics junkie, the small community, and lack of updates, then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Alright, there is a lot to say about this game. I will try to keep this as short as possible while still maintaining all the necessary information. I do not normally write reviews so bare with me on this. There is a reason I am choosing to write this review which you will see towards the end.Now, let's begin with the game itself.This game has been out for just barely more than a year. The staff behind this game have done an absolutely incredible job with quests, with the story line and overall game play.  Sure, there's some little buggy issues here and there, but it's an indie game that hasn't been out long. To expect perfection would be pretty ludicrous. Even EA puts out♥♥♥♥♥♥games and they're a billion dollar corporation.Just like any MMORPG you have the basic classes and subclasses to character creation. Archer, Mage, Healer, Tank and then the subclasses like assassin, warrior ect. This system is pretty much universal but everyone has their own unique ways of doing it. I want to avoid comparing this to runescape, I know this is what everyone is doing. However the ONE thing I will say, is if you are looking for a runescape like game, this is your game.The resource gathering on this game and the profession leveling can be a very painful grind at times. The Community in game is fantastic. You get the occasional jerks that just want to start♥♥♥♥♥♥ but most everyone is very helpful and supportive.The world... even now after 250 hours of game play on this game, I am finding places in this game I didn't even know existed. There's so much to explore, so much to do, there's an insane amount of side quests and story line quests.Most importantly however, is the admin/customer support staff. There is none like this out there. You will not find a friendlier group of guys out there. If you have a problem and need a quick fix, find an online admin, or submit a ticket. Fast response times Monday through Friday and they legitimately seek to help you. The staff is what prompted me to write this review. I could not give this staff enough praise even if I wanted to. If they had the resources as a company like EA, Activision, SEGA, ect, the would would be the limit for these guys.I WANT to rate this game based on potential. For a free to play, pay for benefits game, this game is incredible. It's not a pay to win game by any means. If I were to rate based on potential due to how young of a game this is, I would say 9/10. This game has that kind of potential.However, to give this game a rating as it stands, I would give this game a 7/10. As much praise as I give this game, the only 2 complaints I have about it to drop it from an 8 to a 7 are the fact that the leveling really, really feels like a grind at times and there is somewhat of a lack of customization of armor/weapons. This may get fixed in the future though. There's just a slight lack of weapons/armor content is all.

												It's a pretty okay MMO.I haven't gotten far in the story yet, but that's because I like crafting too much. hahah. The craft system is okay, and you can farm stuff, fish, mine, skin wildlife, cook, tailor, smith, etc. The game doesn't have forced combat classes either. You can just learn skills from any type. Of course eventually it's best to stick to one or two types for the higher level skills... but you can do whatever. The graphics is a bit mediocre, but the upside is that this game isn't even half a GB. I'm sure other hardware demands are much lower as well. So it's a game pretty much anyone can play, especially since it's also free.All'n all, another good game to keep you busy.

												So basically this game came up on my recommended and I thought "wow this looks like old runescape" which I spent countless hours on during my childhood. content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												If you have an old school RuneScape fix, then this game is for you. It is literally the closest MMORPG you can find that is like old school RuneScape that isn't RuneScape. It even has the same holiday events that RuneScape had, such as Christmas Crackers and Party hats. The best part about this game is that it's still early in the games life so everyone is nice and everything is new. I was playing this game before it came to Steam, so there's not much time on my Steam account. I got to level 8 and decided to wait until this game came to Steam so I could play with more people, and now that this game has come out, I'll be playing it a lot more. Don't listen to people who are bashing this game. If you've never played RuneScape, you won't really understand this games feel. But it's still a nice little game to play every once in awhile.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
TL;DROne of the best RPGMMO's i've ever played. It has no 'locked' classes, meaning you can be either male or female character and be ANY build you want and with the new level cap raise hybrid builds are really good. ONE IMPORTANT DOWNSIDE - This game's playerbase is not as high as it was a year or two ago, so if you like populated games then sadly this is not the game for you. That being said; this game is still very fun with a decent community, a really nice story line and tons of quests to do. Well? What are you waiting for? Go on and try it out!Long(er) review versionThe problem with this game is that it's not being advertised, I only stumbled upon it by accident and man am I glad I did. I made many friends from around the globe and I had alot of amazing experiences in this game. This game is a masterpiece considering the small team of developers behind it. You can have more than one character ( up to 16 ) and it definitely has that replayability value.The classes you can pick from are as follow:~Templar (The Tank, you generate the aggro to keep all the mobs focusing only you. It is your job to take all the damage and punishment. The use of pain-killers are advised).~Warrior (Melee two-handed dps class with high AoE dps skills and talents).~Assassin (Melee dual-wielding dps class with high single target dps).~Ranger (Ranged dps class with balanced AoE and single target dps, a bit weaker than melee classes but it has a familiar with really high armor and HP that acts as a single target tank).~Mage (Ranged magic dps class with high AoE and single target dps. Warrior remaining better AoE- and Assassin better single target dps classes. It also has a familiar but unlike Ranger's tanky-wolf, this Elemental does not generate enough aggro to be used as tank, but it does deal good damage and is nice to use when soloing high ranking mobs. This class is also one of the easiest to level as).~Prophet (The Healer, you keep the group alive with healing spells, damage reduction spells and mana/hp regenrating abilities).There are currently three major servers in this game called: Terra (EU), Zephyr (US) and Cleavius (OC). All the other small servers has been merged with these three (US having the highest playerbase and EU just a bit less).EDIT: I completely forgot to talk about professions, so here goes: This game has a really nice system of professions in two 'categories' namely Gathering and Crafting. Here players can mine, farm hunt, etc and then use the gathered materials to level up the respective Crafting profession for example: Hunting -> Leatherworking; Prospecting (mining) along with Crystal Cutting -> Weaponsmithing, Armorsmithing, Jewelery; Gathering -> Alchemy; and the list goes on. If you are only interested in leveling all your Gathering skills, you can sell or trade the materials to players who need it or sell it at vendor price to the npc's.EDIT 2: Sadly the latest major updates made the game p2w in both pvp and pve, mostly in pvp aspects though. While the previous end-game gear had to be obtained by grinding the respective dungeons, one can now obtain even more powerful gear simply by opening your wallet and buying the required materials from other players. This eliminated the need for people to form parties and run dungeons to obtain their gear, which was more fun. Most players grab their parents' credit cards, buys the required materials and outgears all the old players that had to work for their gear. In Conclusion: Despite what is mentioned above, I really recommend you try this game, it's really unique, tons of fun to play with friends or solo and it stands above the rest.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												This game is awesome, it's a lot of fun. Since its free to play there's nothing wrong with trying it out to see for yourself.This is kind of like runescape meets V-wow, its somewhere in the middle. Ten times better than runescape, but probably about a quarter of the players.Its tons of fun to go do quests and stuff, not a ton of players though, but that's to be expected honestly. Its only been really out for about a month and from what i heard it wasn't easily playable at first, but that's changed considerably.However, the interface still needs work butI rarely run into bugs. No jumping kind of is disconcerting not only that but there's a lot of other things that I'd like to more or less be updated to fit more modern games. One big thing was that objects are sometimes larger than they appear annd you more or less have to click a point for your character to move around the object, which is a big thing i run into a lot, camera controls and how everything is put together is a bit condense, espically in some areas where you have to be looking almost straight down to be able to move around properly. But over all its a ton of fun for what it is. Graphics aren't bad, but not excatly the best either. Zones are also kind of weird, I like the idea of being able to run about and get killed by high level mobs. Also pvp was more or less an after thought. All levels are thrown into the arena, while lower levels gets a boost it just shows there aren't enough players pvp'ing to do anything great with it, also there's no real pvp armor or anything like that meaning the system is nearly pointless other than getting a mount and some top layers to cover your armor. Also no player aution house means only venders are there for selling or going out and asking people to trade, which since your voice only really has a limited reach it will get very hard to sell something to other players.Now while that might push some away, this is still an amazing game. It has a ton of room to grow and they are planning on expanding it considerbly.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I enjoy this game a lot more than I thought I would, since I was never able to get into Runescape and that seems to be the most often compared title to Eldevin. I like how there's so many different gathering and crafting skills, and that you can do every one of them on one character, I find it enjoyable just to go on gathering trips and then come back and sort what I have for crafting, which is VERY unlike me, typically. Sure, the graphics are not modern and snazzy, but they hold an appeal for me- I really like the visual style of the game. Small touches like the animation of using a table saw to cut logs into planks are very satisfying.  The music is nice, though quite often a bit too understated. The free to play system of Eldevin is fantastic. There's barely any restrictions at all. That being said, I subbed after a couple of days becuase it's only $6.99. If you are the type of player who will just want to level fast without doing crafting or anything to get to 'endgame', that attitude won't work here. The journey really is the point of this game.I can't say if I'll play Eldevin long-term, but right now I'm enjoying the hell out of it.

												I'm glad I found this game, If your tired of searching for a mmorpg and worn out on the cliche hype, then download this one and get ready for something that you can kick back to and feel that thrill of discovering something new again.  With gameplay kinda like Runescape mixed with Ultima Online, and a dash of Diablo, your not gonna regret this one, easy in and out gameplay, thorough story line, and questing that seems funner than just following arrows, makes it one of the top mmos out there to play, only regret that its not wide known (hardly any advertising on the net).  Its fairly new I believe and that leaves me hoping that much more will be added to this potentially massive and deep game.  Sure the graphics arent eye popping candy, but that is also what sets it apart from the big guys, and thats a good thing, still has plenty of detail and attractiveness to keep you engaged for hours n hours.  Its free to play and is a small download thats easy to play in window mode ( I recommend full screen mode tho ).  Craft, farm,fish, harvest, garden, ect... You could spend all day not killin a thing and still have a good time so come one come all, give it a shot and I bet one day you'll be writing your own review, and trying to get your friends into this world of adventure.!

number of helpful: 67 of 122 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
TL:DR:  If you are stuck with a computer from 1998 or are into something like RuneScape, go for it.  Otherwise there are many other options out there that offer the same experience or better and you may already be involved in them.  Read on for a little more detail.Overall:  No, I didn't play it very long, but it doesn't take me long to get hooked by RPGs if they are for me and many are not.  The thumbs down is mostly that it offers nothing new really.  It's more for people that enjoy this style of game, graphics and community.  In a game like this the community is likely to be very good as it will be small and tight knit, full of nice helpful people that don't need instant gratification.  For that alone, I CAN recommend it, however overall I don't.  For those that want instant gratification, just don't even try it out.Initial:  The initial experience is very linear as it takes you through the tutorial steps, which I feel, most people don't really need to have forced on them these days.  All I really wanted to do was to grab a 2 hander, some 2 hander skills and start bashing my way through quests.  Unfortunately, that is not an option.  You can't even enter the main city without completing your "tutorial" line.  You get to feel the very basics of each archetype; melee, ranged, magic. So you learn the basics of combat quickly.  I am certain that you will of course have more choice once you get through this tutorial wall, but unfortunately I have done these steps in many games before it, felt the same combat, same quests etc.  So as the game felt like more of the same except with outdated visuals, style and mechanics, I grew bored very quickly.  Many likely will.Good Things:  The good thing about all this is, you know what you are getting into.  There seems to be a lot of good lore within the game and it tosses you into that world immediately. There is even a quest to talk to a scribe, catching you up a bit.  Between the archetype skills and the talent tree there seems to be enough skills to keep you interested and the talent trees are rather full of bonuses.  You are also free to choose whatever you want (classless in that regard) and you can use all of the professions (not sure if you can max them all though). There is also good in the fact that it is free to play and it doesn't immediately seem that is any more overbearing with the cash shop than many other free to play games that are considered to have a decent model.  The typical buy inventory, buy xp boosts, cosmetics etc.  The community did seem helpful for those that needed it, although small, but growing thanks to the steam release influx.Conclusion:  There is likely a lot of good in this game for some people, however, for me, it's just not my jam.  I've been there, done that and have moved on to other things, thus I cannot personally recommend it.  However, give it a shot and see, it's free to try and you may or may not like it.  If you do, there's plenty for you to enjoy, including the people. If you don't, nothing lost but maybe a couple hours tops.

												Eldevin started as a browser-based ( client now) MMORPG featuring a rich storyline and hundreds of quests. content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												These are probably some of the worst graphics for a MMO. Avatar graphics look to be from 2001, and building and water graphics from 2004-2005. There is some lag, especially around extra busy areas.And yet, this could be one of the best MMO's out there currently.After having tried different MMO's out including LOTRO, SWTOR, and Spiral Knights, I can now look back at these and see where Eldevin has some of that or has corrected the mistakes these other popular MMO's have failed. Eldevin has a huge world to explore and discover, much like LOTRO. But with much better free roam possibilities. I just did a lvl 7 quest that had lvl 32 Ai.SWTOR pushes you to choose a class. And theres no going back once its made. So your stuck between better powers or better storyline. SWTOR pretty much makes you need a team of players to fight boss's, and to be a higher level than the one your doing. SWTOR nags you about spending rl money on their game, going so far as to raise prices of the items you buy with credits, just for being a free-to-play player! Eldevin's quests are pretty simple and can be soloed pretty much, with a few tougher quests mixed in where you need a team, giving the game a great balance. I can be lvl 8 and take down a lvl 9 Ai. Might be a big fight and I lose extra HP, but least I dont get one-hit and die. Eldevin also lets you pretty much choose which side you want at a relaxing pace. Eventually you'll choose, but its more of just putting points into character traits. Now compare what I said about SWTOR, and Eldevin. You can easily see that Eldevin is the easier, more relaxed, and better able to get into than SWTOR. Eldevin is also really a free-to-play game! As of when Im writing this, you can spend rl money for cosmetics, mounts, mount riding trait, potions, pets, and other knick-knacks. So no new player can come along, throw 100$ into Eldevin, and suddenly be the #1 player in-game, 2 hours later. Thats perhaps one of Eldevin's brightest points.You can also earn reputation points with different factions in Eldevin. All these points do is show what type of quests you have done and lets you earn special vanity(cosmetic items) to wear in-game! That means you have complete freedom to choose which side(s) you choose to support! Though I have not yet found how to earn good reputation points with some of the factions yet, it would appear that they're out there somewhere.Im still wearing the armour and helmet I recieved at level 4. Im now level 9. Most MMO's would drill you to change your gear every 2-3 ranks, with you dieing in battle every time, due to lack of armour stats. Maybe I have stronger weapons and thats why Im not having much trouble, but it seems the only limit to what gear your wearing is up to you making it, and your level.I still have some mixed feelings about the professions, your healing ability, and the combat. The professions are a nusiance at best, yet the majority of new gear you can get for battle, so far, comes from being able to make your own gear(armoursmithing) which requires Mining. The rest, Im not sure about. The majority of players also agree in-game that this is annoying and perhaps the games worst point(next to the graphics in my book). I find woodcutting to be the useless profession as Im still yet to find whats the point of having logs and turning them into boards. Ill see as the game progress's for me. The magical healing ability is, without a doubt, a very useful ally in-game. However, it heals such a tiny amount of your life, that its almost not worth the few second wait as you heal. Potions and eating food heals more in one use than this ability.Combat is very nice! But maybe just a tad unbalanced. Archery is, no doubt, the strongest attack. I can weaken any enemy with 3 archery shots before it can even start its attack on me. They say melee is strong, but archery will end up being the best attack.There is LOTS more I could say showing how great Eldevin is, but why should I? Just download it and see its awesomness yourself. It took me 4-5 minutes to download and took almost no MB. Hunted Cow Studios also has other computer games, including another MMO which has been out either 8 or 10 years depending where you look, and still seems to be going strong. So this game should be great. And with the promise of guilds coming, things will only look to get better. So install the game, enjoy the game, and see how MMO's should really be like! Especially if you played Free Realms or Star Wars: Clone Wars Adventures before they shutdown(oh terrible day!) then you will also love Eldevin.
