												The gameplay in Eldevin is fun, the graphics are ok, not terrible, not great and the story is enjoyable.While the characters and gameplay take some getting use to, there simply are not enough new players to do anything with. Everyone is soloing and ignoring the starter dungeons and group content. Which is fine, but for those of us who would like an opportunity to enjoy the entirety of the game, it was rather lonely.Please keep in mind that I did not join a guild, never visited community forums. This is simply my opinion as someone who grabbed the game and started playing.The character development is fine. However, as you begin to understand more about the game, you come to the conclusion that spending some cash in their shop is inevitable if you want to make any progress. You'll need bag space more than anything. This did not bug me, I do not mind investing in a game I find interesting and fun.In order to get gear in this game past level 28, you need to craft it, or be a part of a guild that will run you through dungeons as you move up and give you what drops. There isn't an auction house for advanced players to offer their goods to others on. However, there is no reason that you couldn't ask for someone to create items for you that already have the skill. I would assume they'd want you to provide materials.I went ahead and purchased the Premium Rhino Pack and Deluxe Pack here on Steam. They helped quite a bit and improved the experience. While leveling itself is quite easy, the grind involved in the crafting system gets annoying. If you're not a crafter, I would suggest joining a guild as soon as possible and making friends with those that have already gone through this grind.I could see an organized guild with solid crafters and dungeon runs doing rather well. All in all, I found the game enjoyable, but do not see it as a free to play game. There is some investment involved to get anywhere.Enjoy!

Posted: November 12, 2015
												very good MMO feels old school with new tech, visuals are old school but i actually like that aspect, the maps are a nice size and full of buildings and POI's at every turn. Lots of mobs to smoke everywhere, quests are nice they don't feel to forced or needed except if you want a story line and some cool gear. the crafting makes sense its not to redundant or ridiculous in its recipes, I have done clothier,farmer,cooking,and alchemy. so far i'm lvl 13 had a nice gent help me run a dungeon a few times and got me my mount with a full set of mage gear. folks and community is nice and helpful even in the chat most will answer questions and will team or trade. I have played a lot of fancy MMO's and never stuck around either because of paywalls, content was convoluted or crafting required the time of an actual day job. this game is as hardcore as you want it to be. I myself find the mage life a good one and hope to see the game move forward with more players. Hell its free why not.

												There are few MMOs these days that give you that undescribable feeling of MMOness. Since quitting WoW I've tried just about every MMO that's around, and haven't found anything that's given me a similar feeling of enjoyment and interest.That is, until I tried Eldevin. Although the graphics and music seem dated, Eldevin creates a strong sense of life to the world.One of the main problems I've found is that it lacks a large player base: often it feels like you're alone in the world unless using global chat.It is fairly similar to Runescape in its crafting, which is incredible. Very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												I must say I am enjoying this more and more as I go along. I have even stopped my WoW subscription. So in short, I would definitely say you should at very least give this a go.On the upside, there are so much content that you don't mind paying the few $/month to be a supporter. Which will give you those points that you need for smooth sailing. You can learn all the crafts and skills. So you can switch classes and take up professions that works with that class without losing progress on anything. The crafting system has got nice depth to it and still makes sense. There are a lot of skills/spells for every class that allows you to build your character the way that fits your play style. You can even use skills from the other classes in your build. Missions missions missions. There are so many. Dailies that for skills, missions for reputation, missions for craft rewards, side missions and main quests. So if you like missions you wont run out quick. Alternatively, if you don't, you can still dungeon grind your way through levels easy enough.Finally, the community is nice and helpful. I have done tons of dungeon runs and never got called a noob or derp if I got stuck not knowing how to proceed when doing a dungeon the first time. People are friendly and helpful, which is rare these days. I am likely missing a lot of things I wanted to add here, but I am rushing to get back in game.There are a few hings that gets to me personally, like small stack sizes in inventory and a lot of back and forth running in quests, but I can also understand why this is so. It is not a pay2win, although it leans towards it. You CAN make it without paying, but it would be quite difficult.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Extremely fun! I expected a runescape rip off but it really is not. This is basically runescape, in-depth. Like take for instance the farming skill. Instead of planting it and waiting it to grow, you have to make sure the plant is watered well and you have to prune the plant if it gets diseased. This game has skills that are really fun to use. For example, the skinning skill enables you to skin animals for their meat,hide and skin. The leatherwork skill allows you to make armour with that leather. Also this game has classes. There are assassins, templars,warriors,rangers and stuff like that. Even through this game is not bursting with content, it is getting updates. This game has alot of potential. Recommended for runescapers who want something new.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												So yeah i was a fan of mmorpg once. Then i quitted my first mmorpg and ever since i coudn't stop anywhere. All of them seemed so alike and i didn't have the money nor the computer to run world of warcraft. So i found myself jumping from game to game trying to find a mmo experience that woud fit my expectations and create that "i don't want to stop playing this game" feeling i had when i was younger - at least a small portion of it- .   Eldevin is exactly that game. It has great mechanics that resembles runescape job system a lot (which is great because runescape has a outstanding job feature). The character customization is poor but this game isn't focused on this minor contents like graphics. It's all about immersive rpg experience with great quest dialogues a good community overall and the possibility of real role play on an mmo experience.10/10 would fail college again

content:

												Extremely fun! I expected a runescape rip off but it really is not. This is basically runescape, in-depth. Like take for instance the farming skill. Instead of planting it and waiting it to grow, you have to make sure the plant is watered well and you have to prune the plant if it gets diseased. This game has skills that are really fun to use. For example, the skinning skill enables you to skin animals for their meat,hide and skin. The leatherwork skill allows you to make armour with that leather. Also this game has classes. There are assassins, templars,warriors,rangers and stuff like that. Even through this game is not bursting with content, it is getting updates. This game has alot of potential. Recommended for runescapers who want something new.

												I'll admit, the graphics aren't really my thing. I don't mid old graphics if they're not trying to be realistic. But other than that, Eldevin is great. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I rate it 5/10 and here's why:The graphics are simple, minimal, solid, old-school and I love it. It's not too much, but it's enough. For the gameplay Eldevin has to offer, the graphics just fit right. The story is actually good. And I'm not usually into the lore of games. But I have read every single quest line and every single dialog that I ran into in Eldevin. I can actually feel my character and what the npcs have to go through and that surprised me. The writing is very well done. This is a huge plus overall.If you liked Runescape and it's leveling mechanics, you will love Eldevin. The crafting system is perfect in it's details. You can use any weapon, any skill, at any times. You get talent points and attribute points for you to shape your character. And the possibilities are very much endless. This game doesn't limit you. It doesn't lock you in one class and one class only. And I love that. IT IS NOT PAY-TO-WIN AND IT'S AWESOME.But, you might ask "Why the low rating, if the game is sooo good?". And the answer, my friend, is that for me it's quite unplayable. I have read through some forums and noticed that the problem is actually very common. It's the FPS rate. Holy poop does it annoy me. I can play games like skyrim on medium, sometimes even high settings with a smooth FPS, even though my computer is not that good. But on Eldevin the FPS rate has never been higher than 17. I have tried different settings, updated my drivers and Java and still it is awful. Whenever I'm in a big map, like the city, or some fields, the FPS is 6-9. Whenever I am near crafting devices - it's 4. Only in small caves or the sewers I get 15-17 FPS and whenever a quest asks me to go to that kind of maps I become a very happy little llama. Some players said "you get used to it". And you do. But when the low FPS ruins your game, by making you defenseless against a gang of mobs, that are 3 levels below you - it's annoying. So, to end my review, I will say that I do recommend this game. I do wish more people would know about this game. And I do believe that old-school mmorpg lovers will indeed fall for this game quickly. But I do warn you all, that the FPS might suck for some of you. And I do wish the developers would work their butts on that. It's not like we are talking about some bug or a glitch. We are talking about the game's PLAYABILITY.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Me and a few of my friends picked this up at the same time as a game to all play together. It's free, has quests and dungeons that you can do together, and we had a lot of fun talking♥♥♥♥♥♥to other players who tried to mine our nodes while we were farming. After a while though xp gain slowed dramatically and it finally became impossible to find space in our inventory and bank between quest items, loot, and profession materials. It became very clear that Hunted Cow wanted us to subscribe for extra xp gain and larger bags. I pay money for content, not the ability to hold more items or aquire adequate amounts of xp so as to avoid running out of questing zones and being forced to grind the same dungeon over and over until the next one opens up. However, I give this game a thumbs up because the time we had playing it was legendary and we reference it quite often, and the fun and funny memories make us laugh.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
 A Short Review for Eldevin	Eldevin has potentials in becoming one of the competitive and immersive MMORPGs out there. It's underrated maybe because of the lack of promotions for the game. The lack of players in the game also deteriorates the quality of the game itself. Maybe focusing on making the community bigger will make this game worthwhile. Despite the cons, it is still worth playing for.  Story - 6/10 (quite the average) Game Play - 9/10 (class and crafting skills) Audio - 7/10 (good ambience sound and background music) Graphics - 5/10 (not-so-great graphics especially the character appearance) Community - 3/10 (population is too low)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												I just started the game and am enjoying it. This game is completely build as you go. There is no locked classes, however there are talent trees that go into class system. However your free to distribute the points into all the talent trees or just focus on a single one.   In addition there is a totally separate leveling system on the crafting/gathering professions.  The different gathering/crafting require grinding but that also means that crafters/gatherers are not a dime a dozen.  This makes the crafter/gatherers more unque rather then common.  Also there is no lock on amount of crafting/gathering so your free to make all your gear or just look for drops.  I enjoy this system because I am not required to have multiple characters to create gear for a single character.  Overall enjoying the thrill of creating a character rather then just grinding a character.  Majority of the quests are multi-path so a great bit of lore while also having small mini quests for additional coin.

I hope I´m wrong about the off Steam time...but I fear I am not :D____________________________________________________Depending on what class you spec into, your experience in-game will differ. Some classes can solo, some will have a really bad time without a party. That said, with the devs giving up on this game to pursue other projects, and the community being more based on nostalgia rather than new players, actually finding a party throughout the levels is going to be a challenge at this state. It was a challenge back at Steam release and that´s where the game reached some of its peak traffic. High levels can - and are sometimes even villing to help you, themselves or with their alow level chars, but if you don´t do the dungeons and quests with a party of your own levels, you will never learn how to play your role properly.  (Only dying a hundred times in Ohdar scar can really teach you a lesson in teamwork! :D)Overall, the best aspect of the game is the crafting/gathering system. That is the part of the game that has the very distinct Runescape feel to it, but alas only some items are even worth crafting and fishing for instance is a reason to become braindead in matter of hours. Whoever maxed fishing is a god damn machine! There is little PvP and since the classes are so poorly balanced for PvP, it sucks balls. Because some classes aren´t viable for PvP, people don´t play them. Because some classes level with more difficulty than others, people don´t play them. *cough* TANKS *cough* So yeah, unbalanced classes ruin this game a lot. Community had always been friendly - unless you are on TA in the middle of a PvP zone. You will die there. Don´t go there if you´re gonna be salty about it. PvE content is superb. I actually even paid attention to the story for once and I am a confirmed story-skipper. Quests/daily quests do offer some variety, but not TOO much. Dungeons are fun, because they are not easy and you can have high levels in your team and still get obliterated if you don´t know how to fight a particular boss or group of enemies. Instances/arenas are there...but meh. Nobody queues for them.Graphics are not everyone´s cup of tea, to me they always looked funny but I don´t really care about this aspect of a game. As long as it doesn´t make my eyes bleed - and it didn´t.The in-game shop is decent, not really P2W although some shady EXP pots and chests of gold are in there (ruining the eco with the currency a bit), but I like that they mostly decided to go with vanity items (basically fancy clothes), pets, mounts etc. that don´t affect gameplay. Compared to other, known P2W MMOs out there, Eldevin is just a couple items shy of being perfect in the F2P model. It didn´t bother me, at least. My advice is, try this for yourself. See if it´s your cup of tea. It would sure be nice to see more people around...might even make me go back to spend another thousand hours in this...oh god send help :D

Product received for free
												TLDR; Look past the dated graphics for a highly recommended game.A great game reminiscent of others like Fallen Earth and even perhaps Runescape, this rpg has a bit of everything with the great bonus of having a very friendly community. You'll see other comments stating the game has died, or that the player base is empty, but the few people around are the pinacle of a great MMO experience.Within the first few hours of playing, I stumbled upon a few other people, all who came up to me and donated gold and gifts without even knowing who I was. There are no bots, it is not pay to win and the story is enjoyable and reasonably unique.Definitely give this game a try (it's only a matter of MB to install!) if you are willing to look past some dated graphics and a small playerbase. Besides, each new player allows the game to grow, and the currently small online group means there is never any lag related to server-side issues.

content:
Posted: January 17
												I really like the concept of eldevin, the combat is nice, the skill tree is nice, the dungeons and raids are cool, and it feels a lot like runescape. I would reccomend trying it but to be honest I don't really play it. The two cons and reasons I don't play eldevin all that much are the playerbase which is very small and the skill system. Don't get me wrong the skill system is nice and has a decent classic mmo pacing from what I experienced but the problem is that all the skills feel the same. You gather resources for every skill, get the uncommon resources as well while gathering resources but not quite enough to process all your resources entirely, buy another resource from a vendor, and finally manufacture an item from the common, uncommon, and brought resource. This is literally the same for all of the skills except scribe I think and I don't know about scribe because it's not early game. This makes it feel repetitive doing any skill, smithing feels like cooking, jewelcraft feels like leather working, etc.The main story is ok but it also takes away from the sense of freedom and makes the game feel like it's putting you through grinding just to do the next story quest which I don't even want to do all that much. I don't care about the king, I don't care about the kingdom, I dont want to join the mages council crap, and I don't want to help the army. I know you could just ignore the main quest but quests are the only decent way to level up after level 9.It's worth a try but it has some shortcomings, it's free though so there's nothing to lose.
